COMMUNICATING EFFECTIVELY WITH DEAF, LATE DEAFENED AND HARD OF HEARING PEOPLE
COMMUNICATING
EFFECTIVELY WITH DEAF,
LATE DEAFENED AND
HARD OF HEARING PEOPLE

A short online self-training
A short online self-training

Privacy policy
Privacy policy

What The Law Says
What The Law Says

Understanding the legal requirements of the Americans with Disabilities Act is a necessary first step in making your facility, program or service communication accessible
Understanding the legal requirements of the
Americans with Disabilities Act is a necessary
first step in making your facility, program or
service communication accessible

Privacy policy
Privacy policy

ADA Title I - Employment
ADA Title I - Employment

No otherwise qualified individual with a disability may be discriminated against in the hiring process and in the workplace. An employee who is Deaf or has a hearing loss may request that reasonable accommodations be provided to ensure equally effective communication access and participation on the job.
No otherwise qualified individual with a
disability may be discriminated against
in the hiring process and in the
workplace. An employee who is Deaf or
has a hearing loss may request that
reasonable accommodations be
provided to ensure equally effective
communication access and
participation on the job.

The Americans with Disabilities Act was signed into law by President Bush in 1991.Title I covers Employment, Title II Obligations of State and Local Governments, Title III Places of Public Accommodation and Title IV Telecommunications.
The Americans with Disabilities Act was signed into law by President Bush in
1991.Title I covers Employment, Title II Obligations of State and Local
Governments, Title III Places of Public Accommodation and Title IV
Telecommunications.

Privacy policy
Privacy policy

ADA Title II - Obligations of State & Local Government Agencies and Public Services
ADA Title II - Obligations of State & Local
Government Agencies and Public Services

State & Local government departments and agencies are prohibited from discriminating against qualified individuals with disabilities in such a way that they are excluded from participation in services, programs, or activities.
State & Local government departments
and agencies are prohibited from
discriminating against qualified
individuals with disabilities in such a
way that they are excluded from
participation in services, programs, or
activities.

The Americans with Disabilities Act was signed into law by President Bush in 1991.Title I covers Employment, Title II Obligations of State and Local Governments, Title III Places of Public Accommodation and Title IV Telecommunications.
The Americans with Disabilities Act was signed into law by President Bush in
1991.Title I covers Employment, Title II Obligations of State and Local
Governments, Title III Places of Public Accommodation and Title IV
Telecommunications.

Privacy policy
Privacy policy

ADA Title III - Obligations of Places of Public Accommodation
ADA Title III - Obligations of Places of Public
Accommodation

No individual may be discriminated against in the full and equal enjoyment of goods, services, facilities, privileges and accommodations in privately operated commercial facilities that are open to the public. Modification or removal of architectural/ programmatic barriers is required only if such changes are readily achievable.
No individual may be discriminated
against in the full and equal enjoyment
of goods, services, facilities, privileges
and accommodations in privately
operated commercial facilities that are
open to the public. Modification or
removal of architectural/ programmatic
barriers is required only if such
changes are readily achievable.

The Americans with Disabilities Act was signed into law by President Bush in 1991.Title I covers Employment, Title II Obligations of State and Local Governments, Title III Places of Public Accommodation and Title IV Telecommunications.
The Americans with Disabilities Act was signed into law by President Bush in
1991.Title I covers Employment, Title II Obligations of State and Local
Governments, Title III Places of Public Accommodation and Title IV
Telecommunications.

Privacy policy
Privacy policy

ADA Title IV - Telecommunications
ADA Title IV - Telecommunications

Every state must establish a Telecommunications Relay Service to ensure equal access to those customers with hearing and speech disabilities.
Every state must establish a
Telecommunications Relay Service to
ensure equal access to those
customers with hearing and speech
disabilities.

The Americans with Disabilities Act was signed into law by President Bush in 1991.Title I covers Employment, Title II Obligations of State and Local Governments, Title III Places of Public Accommodation and Title IV Telecommunications.
The Americans with Disabilities Act was signed into law by President Bush in
1991.Title I covers Employment, Title II Obligations of State and Local
Governments, Title III Places of Public Accommodation and Title IV
Telecommunications.

Privacy policy
Privacy policy

Effective communication must be understood by both parties. For this to happen, the process of communication must be tailored to the person’s communication preferences. In order to understand how the law can be translated into effective communication access, it is necessary to understand the differences between Deaf, oral deaf, hard of hearing and late deafened persons, and their communication preferences.
Effective communication must be
understood by both parties. For this to
happen, the process of communication
must be tailored to the person’s
communication preferences.
In order to understand how the law can be
translated into effective communication
access, it is necessary to understand the
differences between Deaf, oral deaf, hard
of hearing and late deafened persons, and
their communication preferences.

Privacy policy
Privacy policy

A Deaf Person...
A Deaf Person...

...may use American Sign Language (ASL),
...may use American Sign Language (ASL),

gestures, or mime
gestures, or mime

...uses facial expressions in place of voice
...uses facial expressions in place of voice

inflection
inflection

...may choose to use voice
...may choose to use voice

...varies in fluency of reading/writing English
...varies in fluency of reading/writing English

...may use paper and pen as last resort
...may use paper and pen as last resort

...may be involved in the deaf community
...may be involved in the deaf community

Privacy policy
Privacy policy

An Oral Deaf Person...
An Oral Deaf Person...

...may have been born deaf, or have acquired deafness
...may have been born deaf, or have acquired deafness

at an early age
at an early age

…will have been raised in an environment that
…will have been raised in an environment that

supported learning speech and speechreading
supported learning speech and speechreading

...may display varying degrees of speech reading skills
...may display varying degrees of speech reading skills

...may use sign language
...may use sign language

...may vary in fluency of reading and writing English
...may vary in fluency of reading and writing English

...may or may not be involved in the deaf community
...may or may not be involved in the deaf community

Privacy policy
Privacy policy

A Hard of Hearing Person...
A Hard of Hearing Person...

...has acquired a hearing loss ranging from mild to
...has acquired a hearing loss ranging from mild to

profound at some time during his or her life
profound at some time during his or her life

...may benefit from amplification: hearing aids, ALD’s
...may benefit from amplification: hearing aids, ALD’s

…communicates in spoken English or other spoken
…communicates in spoken English or other spoken

language supported by speechreading (lipreading)
language supported by speechreading (lipreading)

…generally will not know sign language
…generally will not know sign language

...will likely function within the ‘hearing’ world
...will likely function within the ‘hearing’ world

Privacy policy
Privacy policy

A Late Deafened Person...
A Late Deafened Person...

…has acquired a profound post-lingual hearing loss
…has acquired a profound post-lingual hearing loss

…will initially continue to use spoken English or
…will initially continue to use spoken English or

other spoken language supported by speech
other spoken language supported by speech

reading
reading

...may eventually learn Signed English, or ASL, as a
...may eventually learn Signed English, or ASL, as a

way to support verbal communication
way to support verbal communication

…may preferentially use CART in complex situations
…may preferentially use CART in complex situations

...may use paper and pen as last resort
...may use paper and pen as last resort

...will likely function within the ‘hearing’ world
...will likely function within the ‘hearing’ world

Privacy policy
Privacy policy

A Deaf - Blind Person
A Deaf - Blind Person

...may have been born with, or acquired their hearing
...may have been born with, or acquired their hearing

loss
loss

...may have been born with, or acquired
...may have been born with, or acquired

blindness/partial loss of sight
blindness/partial loss of sight

...may receive information by tactile communication
...may receive information by tactile communication

...may use ASL and/or fingerspelling
...may use ASL and/or fingerspelling

...may use spoken English
...may use spoken English

...may benefit from high contrast, large print materials
...may benefit from high contrast, large print materials

Understanding Communication preferences is an important part of the picture. Knowing how you can make communication more effective is another.
Understanding Communication
preferences is an important part
of the picture. Knowing how
you can make communication
more effective is another.

Privacy policy

page.enlisting:
Communication Tips Get the person’s attention before starting to communicate Maintain eye contact Keep your face and mouth visible and be sure there is adequate lighting Be aware that having food, gum or other objects in your mouth while talking distorts lip movements Speak clearly and at a moderate pace Use appropriate volume Repeat or rephrase as necessary
Communication Tips
Get the person’s attention before starting to
communicate
Maintain eye contact
Keep your face and mouth visible and be
sure there is adequate lighting
Be aware that having food, gum or other
objects in your mouth while talking distorts
lip movements
Speak clearly and at a moderate pace
Use appropriate volume
Repeat or rephrase as necessary
page.curvetext:
Privacy policy
Privacy policy

More Tips
More Tips

Reduce environmental noise or move to a quieter location
Reduce environmental noise or move to a
quieter location

Use gestures and facial expressions
Use gestures and facial expressions

Have paper and pen on hand
Have paper and pen on hand

Only one speaker at a time
Only one speaker at a time

Give cues when changing subjects
Give cues when changing subjects

Minimize movement while speaking
Minimize movement while speaking

Talk to the person directly - not to the interpreter, CART reporter or companion
Talk to the person directly - not to the
interpreter, CART reporter or companion

Accents or slang expressions may make understanding difficult
Accents or slang expressions may make
understanding difficult

Privacy policy
Privacy policy

Finally, it is very common for people to be embarrassed about having a hearing loss. Some people may deny they have one, while others may not even realize they are affected. Here are some ways to help you identify whether a hearing loss is present or not.
Finally, it is very common for
people to be embarrassed
about having a hearing loss.
Some people may deny they
have one, while others may not
even realize they are affected.
Here are some ways to help
you identify whether a hearing
loss is present or not.

Thank you for taking this short online communication access training! Please note that this is a very abbreviated version of our standard ‘live’ trainings. Feel free to contact us and request one of our professional trainers to attend your facility or event and give you the ‘full’ version!
